abstract.para: In 1998, the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) designed and initiated a large scale, long-term monitoring study of kelp forest ecosystems along portions of the southern, central and northern coast of California and southern Oregon, USA. The program is administered out of the University of California campuses in Santa Cruz and Santa Barbara and funded primarily by the David and Lucile Packard Foundation. The purpose of the study has been to characterize the regional and temporal patterns of kelp forest ecosystem structure and evaluate the relative contributions of biological and environmental variables in explaining observed spatial and temporal patterns. For this purpose, the ecological community and physical structure of kelp forest ecosystems have been surveyed using trained SCUBA divers. The biological structure includes the more conspicuous fishes, invertebrates, and macroalgae. The physical structure includes geomorphological attributes (substratum type and vertical relief). Among other applications, these surveys have informed the design and evaluation of the state-wide network of marine protected areas (MPAs) established by California’s Marine Life Protection Act. Over time, the role of the monitoring program for evaluating the ecological responses to the establishment of the MPAs greatly influenced both the spatial and temporal design of the monitoring program.

keywordSet.keyword: Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO)

intellectualRights.para: This information is released under the Creative Commons license - Attribution - CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). The consumer of these data ("Data User" herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

description.para: The geographic scope of the PISCO kelp forest monitoring program spans southern Oregon and north central, central, and southern California, encompassing three ecoregions distinguished by distinct oceanographic environments. The vast majority of surveys are conducted in central and southern California. In central California site selection was confined to areas that supported kelp forests at the onset of the monitoring program. In southern California site selection included forested and non-forested sites of comparable rocky reef habitat. Surveys are conducted annually, generally from June to late October. To comprehensively and quantitatively characterize the ecological community and geological features at each kelp forest site, five different sampling methods are employed, all of which are conducted visually by SCUBA divers. Sites are surveyed for fishes and benthic organisms separately, with differing transect replication for the two methods (described below). Transects are laid in a stratified random design with non-fixed transects at specified locations (sites) and targeted depth zones. The number and arrangement of these zones depends on the width and slope of the rocky reef at each site. Fish transects and benthic macroalgae and invertebrate transects overlap with, but are spatially distinct from one another. Often, benthic sampling is conducted in the early part of the summer, with fish sampling commencing later in the summer and continuing into the fall, in order to constrain the seasonality of sampling.
Fish surveys (entity: PISCO kelp forest fish data)

The density of all conspicuous fishes (i.e. species whose adults are longer than 10 cm and visually detectable by SCUBA divers) are visually recorded along replicate 2m wide by 2m tall by 30m long (120m3) transects. In pairs, one diver surveys this volume along the reef surface (searching within cracks and crevices), while another surveys the same volume roughly one third to one half up into the water column (i.e. “mid-water”) above the benthic diver, depending on visibility and bottom depth. Canopy transects of the same dimensions as the mid-water and bottom transects are surveyed at a subset of sites, mainly to target juvenile fish recruiting to the kelp canopy. Canopy transects are only done where kelp canopy extends to the surface and are usually completed separately from the bottom and midwater transects. On canopy transects, the fish counter swims 2m below the surface counting fishes in the top two meters of the water column. Typically, for each portion of the water column sampled, three 30m long transects are distributed end-to-end and 5-10m apart at each of the 5m, 10m, 15m, and 20m isobaths (with additional 25m transects conducted by VRG where habitat is available). Survey depths may vary based on reef topography. Counts on mid-water and bottom transects are eventually combined, thereby generating 12 replicate transects for each site for analyses. At sites with narrow kelp beds, particularly in parts of the Northern Channel Islands, only two zones are sampled, with four transects in each depth zone for a total of eight replicate transects. Fish transects are generally only conducted with at least 3m of horizontal visibility. The total length (TL) of each fish observed is estimated to the closest 1cm. For each transect, divers record the transect depth, horizontal visibility along each transect, water temperature, and sea state (surge), and percent of the transect volume occupied by kelp (PISCO only).
Benthic swaths for algae and invertebrate densities (entity: PISCO kelp forest swath data)

The density of conspicuous, individually distinguishable macroalgae and macroinvertebrates (i.e. organisms larger than 2.5 cm and visually detectable by SCUBA divers) are visually recorded along replicate 2m wide by 30m long (60m2) transects. For select species (e.g., sea urchins), high densities are spatially subsampled to allow extrapolation to three separate 20m2 segments of the transect. Typically, two 30m long transects are distributed end-to-end and 5-10m apart at each of the 5m, 12.5m, and 20m isobaths (with additional 25m transects conducted by VRG where habitat is available). This usually generates six replicate transects for each site. At sites with narrow kelp beds, particularly in parts of the Northern Channel Islands, only two zones are sampled, with two transects in each depth zone for a total of four replicate transects. Giant kelp (Macrocystis pyrifera) and bull kelp (Nereocystis luetkeana) individuals are enumerated when they reach a stipe height of > 1m, and the number of giant kelp stipes for each individual are also counted. Size cut-offs for inclusion of other understory kelps and large macroalgae, and descriptions of size cut-offs for invertebrates are described in the taxonomic table.
Benthic point contact for algae and invertebrate percent cover (entity: PISCO kelp forest UPC data)

The percent cover of sessile non-individually distinguishable macroalgae and macroinvertebrates (e.g. colonial invertebrates, foliose macroalgae) are visually recorded along the same replicate 30m long transects used to conduct benthic swath surveys. Typically, two 30m long transects are distributed end-to-end and 5-10m apart at each of the 5m, 12.5m, and 20m isobaths (with additional 25m transects conducted by VRG where habitat is available). This usually generates six replicate transects for each site. At sites with narrow kelp beds, particularly in parts of the Northern Channel Islands, only two zones are sampled, with two transects in each depth zone for a total of four replicate transects. At each meter mark along the 30m transect, the diver records the underlying substrate (bedrock, boulder, cobble, or sand), vertical relief (maximum vertical distance in a 0.5x1m box centered on the point, categorized into 0-10cm, 10cm-1m, 1-2m, and >2m bins), and cover (non-mobile primary space holding organism or bare substrate type). An additional category consisting of a small subset of specific organisms which may be ephemeral, and tend to create a layer over primary space holders are recorded, when present, as a superlayer. Examples include low-lying, very large-bladed macroalgae such as Laminaria farlowii, brittle stars, drift algae, and abalone in the Northern region. Superlayer classifications vary by survey region, and are further defined in the taxonomic table.
Size surveys for selected algae and invertebrates (entity: PISCO kelp forest size frequency data)

Size frequency measurements of body size of targeted invertebrate species (e.g., red and purple urchins, abalone in the genus Haliotis, spiny lobsters, seastars) are recorded by divers both along benthic transects and at random locations within a study site. Organisms are generally measured by divers in situ, and measured sizes correspond with test diameter for urchins, length of longest arm for seastars, shell length for shelled mollusks, carapace length for lobsters, and total turgid length for sea cucumbers. In the case of urchins sampled by UCSB and VRG in Southern California, large numbers of individuals may be collected in bags and brought aboard the research vessel to facilitate measurement.
Quadrat surveys (entity: PISCO kelp forest quadrat data)

Quadrat sampling is conducted by counting organisms within a 1x1m PVC folding quadrat designed to capture densities of select species (recruits and smaller or cryptic invertebrates and algae). Six quadrats are placed at meters 2, 7, 12, 17, 22 and 27 along the same 30m transects used for benthic sampling (swath and UPC). Quadrat surveys were done only at sites in southern California surveyed by UCSB. Quadrat sampling was discontinued after 2010.

project.title: Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO)
project.funding: David and Lucile Packard Foundation, Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation

dataTable.entityDescription: Transect-level counts (densities) of macroinvertebrates and select macroalgae.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The academic partner campus that conducted the survey
The code describing the sampling technique and monitoring program that conducted each survey

codeDefinition.definition: Subtidal swath survey conducted by the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) Program

attribute.attributeDefinition: The designated year associated with the annual survey. In most cases, survey_year and year are the same. In rare cases, surveys are completed early in the year following the designated survey year. In these cases, survey_year will differ from year
Year that the survey was conducted
Month that the survey was conducted
Day that the survey was conducted

The unique site where the survey was performed (as defined in the site table). This site refers to a specific GPS location and is often associated with a geographic placename. Often, multiple site replicates will be associated with a single placename, and will be delineated with additional geographical or directional information (e.g. North/South/East/West/Central - N/S/E/W/CEN, Upcoast/Downcoast - UC/DC)

textDomain.definition: The unique site where the survey was performed (as defined in the site table). This site refers to a specific GPS location and is often associated with a geographic placename. Often, multiple site replicates will be associated with a single placename, and will be delineated with additional geographical or directional information (e.g. North/South/East/West/Central - N/S/E/W/CEN, Upcoast/Downcoast - UC/DC)

attribute.attributeDefinition: A division of the site into 2 to 4 categories representing onshore-offshore stratification associated with targeted bottom depths for transects

codeDefinition.definition: Depth zone targeting roughly 5m of water depth, or the inner edge of the reef (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 10-15m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 20m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique transect replicate within each site and zone

textDomain.definition: The unique transect replicate within each site and zone

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level or higher order groupings. Generally, for invertebrates and algae, the classcode is comprised of the first three letters of the genus, and the first three letters of the species, with some exceptions

textDomain.definition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level or higher order groupings. Generally, for invertebrates and algae, the classcode is comprised of the first three letters of the genus, and the first three letters of the species, with some exceptions

attribute.attributeDefinition: The count is the number of individuals of a given classcode (of a given size when applicable) per transect

For Macrocystis pyrifera, this represents the number of individual stipes growing for each individual. For a select number of invertebrate species that are measured on swath transects, this represents the size (in centimeters) of the following: test diameter for urchins, length of longest arm for seastars, shell length for abalone, carapace length for lobsters, total turgid length for sea cucumbers

For some years echinoderm disease was recorded on transects for select species. When systematic observation for disease was conducted, disease is indicated here. Where blank, disease was not evaluated.

codeDefinition.definition: Individual was inspected and no was disease observed
Some form of disease was observed

attribute.attributeDefinition: Depth of the transect estimated by the diver
The diver who conducted the survey transect

attribute.attributeDefinition: Free text notes taken at the time of the sample, or added at the time of data entry

textDomain.definition: Free text notes taken at the time of the sample, or added at the time of data entry

attribute.attributeDefinition: In cases when specific sites have been surveyed by multiple campuses using different site names, this variable indicates the alternative (historical) site name

attribute.attributeDefinition: A division of the site into 2 to 4 categories representing onshore-offshore stratification associated with targeted bottom depths for transects

codeDefinition.definition: Depth zone targeting roughly 5m of water depth, or the inner edge of the reef (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 10-15m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 20m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique transect replicate within each site and zone

textDomain.definition: The unique transect replicate within each site and zone

attribute.attributeDefinition: The code indicating which of four types of data are collected on each point. Categories may be SUBSTRATE, RELIEF, COVER and SUPERLAYER. Percent cover should be calculated for each category separately. For SUPERLAYER, the total number of points will not necessarily equal the targeted number of points surveyed in each of the other categories (i.e. superlayer is specific to certain organisms that are only included if present).

codeDefinition.definition: Primary space holding, non-mobile organism or bare substrate type present at each point, cover types are defined in taxonomic table

Physical relief is measured as the greatest vertical relief that exists within a 1m wide section across the tape and a 0.5m section along that tape that is centered over the point. Relief categories can be 0-10cm, 10cm-1m, 1-2m, and >2m
Substrate type underlying each point. Substrate categories include bedrock , boulder, cobble, and sand and are further defined in the taxonomic table

Superlayer includes a small subset of specific organisms which may be ephemeral, and tend to create a layer over primary space holders. Examples include low-lying, very large-bladed macroalgae such as Laminaria farlowii, brittle stars, and drift algae and in the Northern region abalone are recorded as a superlayer when occupying the space at the point. Not recorded at all points, only where present

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level, higher order, or morphological groupings. Generally, for invertebrates and algae, the classcode is comprised of the first three letters of the genus, and the first three letters of the species, with some exceptions, and upc organisms are often classified by common names for groups of species

textDomain.definition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level, higher order, or morphological groupings. Generally, for invertebrates and algae, the classcode is comprised of the first three letters of the genus, and the first three letters of the species, with some exceptions, and upc organisms are often classified by common names for groups of species

attribute.attributeDefinition: The number of points of a given category and classcode per transect

Percent cover, calculated by dividing the number of points of a given category and classcode by the total number of points of a category per transect. The percent cover of superlayer is calculated by dividing the number of points of a superlayer classcode by the total number of points in the cover category, since superlayers are not present at all points.
Depth of the transect estimated by the diver
The diver who conducted the survey transect

codeDefinition.definition: Subtidal size frequency survey conducted by the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) Program

Subtidal swath survey conducted by the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) Program. Sizes recorded as part of swath surveys are duplicated in the size frequency dataset.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The location where the size observation was recorded: RANDOM indicates sizes measures across the general site that were not specifically located on the swath/upc transect, TRANSECT indicates sizes measured on the swath/upc transects, and SIZE_TRANSECT applies to HSU only where specific size frequency transects are conducted separately from swath/upc transects

codeDefinition.definition: Size measurements were collected across the general site and were not specifically located on the swath/upc transect
Size measurements were collected from the swath/upc transects. If method is swath, then this information was collected by the swath diver as part of the swath survey.

attribute.attributeDefinition: A division of the site into 2 to 4 categories representing onshore-offshore stratification associated with targeted bottom depths for transects. If size information is not associated with a specific zone this will be left blank

codeDefinition.definition: Depth zone targeting roughly 5m of water depth, or the inner edge of the reef (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 10-15m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 20m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique transect replicate within each site and zone. If size information is not associated with a specific transect this will be left blank.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level or higher order groupings. Generally, for invertebrates and algae, the classcode is comprised of the first three letters of the genus, and the first three letters of the species, with some exceptions

attribute.attributeDefinition: The number of individuals of a given classcode and size observed at the finest spatial scale indicated (site, zone, or transect)

Size (in centimeters) of observation. For specific species groups, measured sizes correspond with test diameter for urchins, length of longest arm for seastars, shell length for shelled mollusks, carapace length for lobsters, total turgid length for sea cucumbers
For some years echinoderm disease was recorded for select species. When systematic observation for disease was conducted, disease is indicated here. Where blank, disease was not evaluated.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The designated year associated with the annual survey. In most cases, survey_year and year are the same. In rare cases, surveys are completed early in the year following the designated survey year. In these cases, survey_year will differ from year

attribute.attributeDefinition: A division of the site into 2 to 4 categories representing onshore-offshore stratification associated with targeted bottom depths for transects

codeDefinition.definition: Depth zone targeting roughly 10m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 5m of water depth, or the inner edge of the reef (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 20m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 15m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The horizontal placement of the transect within the water column. Includes BOT: bottom transects placed at the seafloor, MID: midwater transects placed at roughly half the depth of the seafloor, and CAN: canopy transects placed at the surface to survey the top two meters of the water column and kelp canopy (when present)

codeDefinition.definition: Transect placed on the seafloor and the lower 2m of the water column surveyed
Transect placed at the surface and the upper 2m of water column and kelp canopy surveyed. Canopy transects are only conducted when kelp is present and forms a canopy at the surface

When an inner transect is too shallow to allow both canopy and midwater transects without overlapping, level is coded as CNMD and transects can be ascribed to either midwater or canopy (applies to UCSB only)
Transect placed in the midwater, at roughly half of the depth of the seafloor (depending on visibility)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique transect replicate within each site, zone, and level

textDomain.definition: The unique transect replicate within each site, zone, and level

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level or higher order groupings. Generally, for fishes, the classcode is comprised of the first letter of the genus, and the first three letters of the species, with some exceptions

textDomain.definition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level or higher order groupings. Generally, for fishes, the classcode is comprised of the first letter of the genus, and the first three letters of the species, with some exceptions

attribute.attributeDefinition: The count is the number of individuals of a given classcode of a given size per transect
The total length of an individual or group of individuals (of the same length) OR the average total length for a group of fish where a range in lengths is specified (rounded to the nearest cm)
The minimum size of the sampled class, used only when a range of sizes was recorded for a group of individuals of a species
The maximum size of the sampled class, used only when a range of sizes was recorded for a group of individuals of a species
The sex classification for sexually dimorphic species where sex can be distinguished visually and is recorded. For some species, individuals with juvenile markings are also indicated here

codeDefinition.definition: Fish has external morphological features consistent with a female
Fish has markings consistent with a juvenile life phase. Not always recorded
Fish has external morphological features consistent with a male
Fish has external morphological features consistent with both male and female (applies to sex changing fishes such as California sheephead)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The diver who conducted the survey transect

textDomain.definition: The diver who conducted the survey transect

attribute.attributeDefinition: Depth of the transect estimated by the diver
The diver's estimation of horizontal visibility on each transect. Measured by reeling in the transect tape and noting the distance at which the end of the tape can first be seen
The temperature on each transect measured by the diver's computer
The diver's estimation of magnitude of horizontal displacement on each transect

codeDefinition.definition: Significant surge, diver moved out of transect bounds when not holding on
Surge causing noticeable lateral movement, diver must compensate

attribute.attributeDefinition: The diver's estimation of the percent of the transect, by volume, that is occupied by kelp. This estimation is specific to the level of the transect that is being surveyed (i.e. excluding canopy transects, this not an estimation of surface canopy but of the amount of kelp within the transect at the specified level)

codeDefinition.definition: 0% of transect volume occupied by kelp
1-33% of transect volume occupied by kelp
34-66% of transect volume occupied by kelp
67-100% of transect volume occupied by kelp

Often, multiple site replicates will be associated with a single placename, and will be delineated with additional geographical or directional information (e.g. North/South/East/West/Central - N/S/E/W/CEN, Upcoast/Downcoast - UC/DC)

textDomain.definition: The unique site where the survey was performed (as defined in the site table). This site refers to a specific GPS location and is often associated with a geographic placename. Often, multiple site replicates will be associated with a single placename, and will be delineated with additional geographical or directional information (e.g. North/South/East/West/Central - N/S/E/W/CEN, Upcoast/Downcoast - UC/DC)

attribute.attributeDefinition: A division of the site into 2 to 4 categories representing onshore-offshore stratification associated with targeted bottom depths for transects.

codeDefinition.definition: Depth zone targeting roughly 5m of water depth, or the inner edge of the reef (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 10-15m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)
Depth zone targeting roughly 20m of water depth (actual depth will vary depending on site topography)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique transect replicate within each site and zone.

textDomain.definition: The unique transect replicate within each site and zone.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique quadrat replicate within each site, zone and transect.

textDomain.definition: The unique quadrat replicate within each site, zone and transect.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level or higher order groupings. Generally, for invertebrates and algae, the classcode is comprised of the first three letters of the genus, and the first three letters of the species, with some exceptions

textDomain.definition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level or higher order groupings. Generally, for invertebrates and algae, the classcode is comprised of the first three letters of the genus, and the first three letters of the species, with some exceptions

attribute.attributeDefinition: The number of individuals of a given classcode and size observed at the finest spatial scale indicated (site, zone, transect, and quadrat)
Depth of the size observation estimated by the diver
The diver who recorded the organism

textDomain.definition: The diver who recorded the organism

attribute.attributeDefinition: Free text notes taken at the time of the sample, or added at the time of data entry

textDomain.definition: Free text notes taken at the time of the sample, or added at the time of data entry

attribute.attributeDefinition: In cases when specific sites have been surveyed by multiple campuses using different site names, this variable indicates the alternative (historical) site name

textDomain.definition: In cases when specific sites have been surveyed by multiple campuses using different site names, this variable indicates the alternative (historical) site name

dataTable.entityDescription: Species (and species-grouping) code descriptions, taxonomic classifications, and sampling histories for all sampled organisms.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The academic partner campus associated with each sample type and monitoring history
The type of survey in which a particular taxonomic code is used. These correspond to the major PISCO subtidal community survey types: fish, swath, upc (uniform point contact), and size-frequency

Defines types of observations within a particular survey type. Examples include SUBSTRATE, RELIEF and COVER which are types of classifications within the UPC sample-type methodology. And INVERT and ALGAE are subtypes within the swath sample-type

codeDefinition.definition: Subset of sample method swath, where organism type is algae
Subset of sample method upc, primary substrate holding organism or non-biological cover type
Subset of sample method swath, where organism type is invertebrate
Subset of sample method upc, category of vertical relief in a defined area around each point
Subset of sample method upc, substrate type at each point
Subset of sample method upc, specialized category to record species which overgrow other benthic organisms and may be ephemeral. Not recorded for all points, only when present
Subset of sample method swath, applies only to transects with no organisms (where algae or invertebrate classification does not apply)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level or higher order groupings

textDomain.definition: The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the taxonomic table. This refers to a code that defines the Genus and Species that is identified, a code that represents a limited number of species that can't be narrowed down to one species, or in some cases family-level or higher order groupings

attribute.attributeDefinition: The scientific kingdom name, will be NA for non-living, and non-biological classcodes

textDomain.definition: The scientific kingdom name, will be NA for non-living, and non-biological classcodes

attribute.attributeDefinition: The scientific phylum name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

textDomain.definition: The scientific phylum name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

attribute.attributeDefinition: The scientific class name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

textDomain.definition: The scientific class name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

attribute.attributeDefinition: The scientific order name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

textDomain.definition: The scientific order name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

attribute.attributeDefinition: The scientific family name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

textDomain.definition: The scientific family name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

attribute.attributeDefinition: The scientific genus name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

textDomain.definition: The scientific genus name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

attribute.attributeDefinition: The scientific species name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

textDomain.definition: The scientific species name, will be NA for higher level groupings, non-living, and non-biological classcodes

attribute.attributeDefinition: The scientific genus and species if applicable. If a classcode is comprised of a higher-level taxonomic grouping, the higher level taxonomic classification is listed. Specific species groupings, non-living, or non-biological classcodes are described here.

textDomain.definition: The scientific genus and species if applicable. If a classcode is comprised of a higher-level taxonomic grouping, the higher level taxonomic classification is listed. Specific species groupings, non-living, or non-biological classcodes are described here.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The source of the taxonomic identifier. For all classcodes associated with living organisms, the source is the World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS, http://www.marinespecies.org/), for non-living, non-biological, and some groupings, the codes are defined by the specific project (PISCO Kelp Forest Monitoring Program)

codeDefinition.definition: When a classcode is not defined by a specific taxonomic ranking (e.g. family, species) the classcode is defined by the specific project (PISCO Kelp Forest Monitoring Program)
AphiaID associated with the species or other taxonomic group

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique numeric identifier for one or more taxonomic groupings as defined in the Aphia database: https://www.marinespecies.org/about.php#what_is_aphia, will be NA for non-living, and non-biological classcodes

textDomain.definition: The unique numeric identifier for one or more taxonomic groupings as defined in the Aphia database: https://www.marinespecies.org/about.php#what_is_aphia, will be NA for non-living, and non-biological classcodes

attribute.attributeDefinition: The common name or description for a species or a higher taxonomic grouping

textDomain.definition: The common name or description for a species or a higher taxonomic grouping

attribute.attributeDefinition: The notes describing how a classcode is sampled or which species are included in higher taxonomic level classcodes

textDomain.definition: The notes describing how a classcode is sampled or which species are included in higher taxonomic level classcodes

attribute.attributeDefinition: The description of the size cut-off (in centimeters) for inclusion in sampling. This generally applies to organisms sampled on swath surveys. The size is indicated in addition to the corresponding measurement dimension for specific organisms

textDomain.definition: The description of the size cut-off (in centimeters) for inclusion in sampling. This generally applies to organisms sampled on swath surveys. The size is indicated in addition to the corresponding measurement dimension for specific organisms

attribute.attributeDefinition: The record of whether a classcode was sampled by the indicated group in 1999. 'yes' indicates that the organism was sampled. These columns are used to track sampling history, so that zeros are not assigned to organisms that were not sampled

dataTable.entityName: PISCO kelp forest site lookup table
dataTable.entityDescription: Site table with coordinate, year sampled, and MPA information associated with each site.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The academic partner campus associated with each sampling site for a given year
Survey type and monitoring group associated with each site in each year

codeDefinition.definition: Subtidal fish survey conducted by the Cooperative Research and Assessment of Nearshore Ecosystems (CRANE) Program
Subtidal fish survey conducted by the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) Program
Subtidal size frequency survey conducted by the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) Program
Subtidal swath survey conducted by the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) Program
Subtidal upc survey conducted by the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) Program
Subtidal quadrat survey conducted by the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) Program

attribute.attributeDefinition: The designated year associated with the annual survey. In most cases, survey_year and year are the same. In rare cases, surveys are completed early in the year following the designated survey year. In these cases, survey_year will differ from year
Year that the survey was conducted

The unique site where the survey was performed. This site refers to a specific GPS location and is often associated with a geographic placename. Often, multiple site replicates will be associated with a single placename, and will be delineated with additional geographical or directional information (e.g. North/South/East/West/Central - N/S/E/W/CEN, Upcoast/Downcoast - UC/DC)

textDomain.definition: The unique site where the survey was performed. This site refers to a specific GPS location and is often associated with a geographic placename. Often, multiple site replicates will be associated with a single placename, and will be delineated with additional geographical or directional information (e.g. North/South/East/West/Central - N/S/E/W/CEN, Upcoast/Downcoast - UC/DC)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Site latitude in WGS84. Often the specific site location is associated with a boat anchor point. If multiple anchor points are associated with a single site, this may be represent a represenatitive location for the site, or the centroid of the site

Site longitude in WGS84. Often specific site location is associated with a boat anchor point. If multiple anchor points are associated with a single site, this may be represent a represenatitive location for the site, or the centroid of the site
Name of Marine Protected Area with which the site is associated

textDomain.definition: Name of Marine Protected Area with which the site is associated

attribute.attributeDefinition: Marine Protected Area designation (level of protection), or reference for non-MPA sites
Site is an MPA site or a reference site

codeDefinition.definition: Site is outside of an MPA

otherEntity.entityDescription: Text document describing the methods for each of the 5 survey types included in the package (fish, swath, UPC, size frequency, and quadrat

unit.name: percent
unit.description: ratio of two quantities as percent composition (1:100)
